content.description:
Thoughtful moves.

Start near Right edge of Right lower face, up 30ft to ledge. One step Left, then up dark rock to top. Finish about 3 ft left of directional bolt.

FA - Naming + First Ascent style - - >

See the Silver Lake area page

.

: The rock on and near this route has not been climbed much yet, and some of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber.

content.description:
Low crux, then fun climbing above.

. . . (upper part fun even if don't try low crux -- by lowering in).

Start on 5-ft-high light rock to right of dark-rock alcove / right-leaning groove.

Get established on the light rock, then big step left across the dark rock to reach light rock on its other side. Next up that light rock, then up ridge to finish at directional bolt.

. . . Variation finish (unprotected) onto rock knob just above R from directional bolt.

content.description:
Lots of thoughtful moves with some slopiness.

Start on Left side of Right lower face, just Right of dirty gully. Up along side of dirty gully, trending Left to stay near the gully. Pass just left of bulge, and up Left side of upper Right face.

. . . Variation: Finish not so left-ward -- to the higher directional bolt above middle of face.

FA - Naming + First Ascent style - - >

See the Silver Lake area page

.

content.description:
Interesting moves in a variety of situations, first easy up face, next steeper up + traversing (sustained delicate footwork with thoughtful handholds) - finish up less-difficult ridge in middle of gully (or stemming the gully).

. . . (arete section could be reached more easily by first climbing lower part of the route Central Gully)

Start up Right side of lower Left face to reach steeper rock. Diagonal up right around edge of steep section.

. . . Variation 1 (top-rope): Just stop after the 5.4-5.5 climbing and lower off when reach steep.

. . . Variation 2: Up over Left side of steep section (similar difficulty, but ends sooner).

Get hands on big horizonatal, next traverse horizontal right into gully - (perhaps a bit downward?) - to reach bottom of non-tall arete / narrow ridge in middle of gully.  Up the ridge to top of gully.

. . . When making the traverse into the gully then up the non-tall ridge, this route follows the light-blue bolts. The gray-metallic bolts are for the route "Central Gully". Except there is one light-blue out far right higher up which is for "Central Gully" (but should not cause any confusion); and the light-blue bolt just below the top anchor is mainly for "Central Gully" - (though some leaders of this route might want to clip it anyway).

. . .  (Variation Mid-Route: Instead of following the non-tall arete, step right across ridge into main gully, to join the route "Central Gully").

Finish to bolts-with-ramshorn-lower-off anchor on knob above right from top of gully.

warning

: The rock on and near this route has not been climbed much yet, and some of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber.
content.protection:
10 intermediate Lead-protection to bolts-with-ring anchor.

. . . Bolt studs are 80mm x 10mm wedge bolts, 316 Stainless steel.

. . . Hangers are 304 Stainless steel.

. . . All installed 2019.

. . . Anchor details see

the route Central Gully

.

content.description:
Interesting face climbing -- in stages.

pitch 1

: Get to the bottom by going up left from base of sector 7 on herd path to below wide gully full of loose rocks. Start up the short slab just Left past the bottom of that loose gully. Diagonal up left above plants, then up to the left "summit". Walk across rather wide grassy ledge to right side of another slab. Up the right side where it's easy enough, then left up to big tree at top of slab as belay anchor.

. . . Variation P1 finish (harder like 5.5 or at least 5.4): Instead climb next slab near its center, directly up to big tree as anchor.

pitch 2

: Around behind big tree, straight up face just left of steeper Left Face routes of this sector. Next trend slightly left to tan rounded rock. Around its left side to finish at big dead gnarly tree as belay anchor.

descent

: Obvious strategy is to rappel.

At the top of pitch 2 is a loop of 9.8mm-diameter climbing rope with double-fisherman's / grapevine knot around big branch of big healthy pine tree -- with 1/4 inch bar-diameter Plated-steel Snap-link attached. Installed 2019.

At the top of pitch 1 is a loop of 9.8mm-diameter climbing rope with double-fisherman's / grapevine knot around the trunk of big gnarly dead tree -- with 1/4 inch bar-diameter Plated-steel Snap-link attached. Installed 2019.

. . (If not sure you trust either of those set-ups for your rappel, then for sure bring your own gear to supplement them).

top-roping

: Each pitch

could

be top-roped. But . . .

note

that while some parties might trust the single Snap-link on the loop of rope for holding a rappel rope in a static position which a climber is hanging in rappel from it, trusting a single Snap-link to hold a rope being moved and started and stopped in different directions is surely a greater level of risk. Therefore it is highly recommended to use your locking carabiner to hold the rope while belaying a climber attached to it.

warning

: The rock on and near this route has not been climbed much yet, and some of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber.

content.description:
Some worthwhile moves - (perhaps think of it as a harder version of the route "Far Left Scramble").

Start above behind big healthy pine tree at high left end of base of this sector. See white-ish face just right of two wide cracks / narrow gullies, a few feet left of the inside corner at left edge of steeper Left Face of this sector.

Straight up that. Next along left side of ridge. Aim for smaller light-colored rounded rock below left from larger tan rounded rock. Finish over that to big dead gnarly tree.

top-roping

: See the suggestions and warnings for the route "Far Left Scramble".

descent

: See the suggestions and warnings for the route "Far Left Scramble".

warning

content.description:
Sustained thoughtful moves (including crossing a little bulge).

Start above behind big healthy pine tree at high left end of base of this sector. Up between two wide cracks / narrow gullies (not using either), passing just right of small tree. Next cross left-trending diagonal bulge (just right of vertical crack without using it). On up to finish over slopy left side of smaller light-colored rounded rock below left from larger tan rounded rock up to big dead gnarly tree.

top-roping

: See the suggestions and warnings for the route "Far Left Scramble".

descent

: See the suggestions and warnings for the route "Far Left Scramble".

content.description:
Interesting stemming + palming. Starts easy, then gets progressively trickier toward the top.

Up the left-trending (loose) (dirty) gully between the two lower faces. Higher up where it gully splits, bear Right.

. . Variation: Instead climb the little arete up the center of the gully (see the route "Left Face Right Edge Plus").

Most of the main route stays to left of the lead-protection bolts to the right of the gully. And all the main route stays to the right of the ridge in the middle of the upper gully.

warning

: The rock on and near this route has not been climbed much yet, and some of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber.
content.protection:
7 or 8 intermediate Lead-protection bolts to bolts-with-ramshorn top anchor.

. . . Bolts and hangers all Stainless steel, bolts 80mm x 10mm wedge bolts -- installed 2019.

The locations of most of these intermediate bolts has been designed to reduce impact hitting structures in the gully in case of a leader falling --

not

to indicate where the best climbing goes -- so generally it works better to climb to the left of the line of bolts.

Top anchor is two 80mmx10mm wedge bolts with hangers (Stainless steel) connected by 3-link and 5-link chains and three quick-links (Plated steel), with ramshorn (pigstail) rappel / lower-off fixture on the lowest quick-link -- installed 2019. Ramshorn and lower hanger are 316 Stainless steel.

Top-Rope: For ideas on how to set up Top-Roping - - >

See the Erb sector area page

.
